questions.text: Which among the following does the graph given below depict?
questions.solution:
The graph given above depicts the Haldane effect.

The binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This is known as the Haldane effect. It helps in the transport of CO2 from the tissues to the lungs. The graph shows small portions of two CO2 dissociation curves:

  • When the PO2 is 100 mm Hg, which is the case in the blood capillaries of the lungs.
  • When the PO2 is 40 mm Hg, which is the case in the tissue capillaries.

At the normal PCO2 of 45 mm Hg in the tissues represented by point A, 52 volume percent of CO2 combines with the blood. Upon entering the lungs, the PCO2 falls to 40 mm Hg and the PO2 rises to 100 mm Hg. The increase in PO2 shifts the CO2 dissociation curve from the top curve to the lower curve, so the CO2 content falls to point B.

Thus, the Haldane effect approximately doubles the amount of CO2 released from the blood in the lungs and the amount picked up by the tissues.

(Remember - HaLdane effect occurs in Lungs and causes Left shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve)

Other options:

Option A: Bohr effect: A right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve in response to an increase in blood CO2 and hydrogen ions, enhances the release of O2 from the blood in the tissues. This enhances the oxygenation of the blood in the lungs.

Option B: Henry's Law in Respiration: The amount of oxygen that dissolves into the bloodstream is directly proportional to the partial pressure of oxygen in alveolar air.

Option D: Boyle's Law: The pressure of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to its volume if its temperature is kept constant.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male was planned for an elective open inguinal hernia repair. The patient also had a history of heart surgery 8 months back with the placement of a drug-eluting stent and currently on dual antiplatelet therapy. When should this anti-platelets be stopped before the current elective surgery?
questions.solution:
The antiplatelets are not be stopped in patients with drug-eluting stents until they have completed 12 months of dual antiplatelet therapy.

Similarly, the antiplatelets are not discontinued in the patients with bare-metal stents until they have completed 1 month of dual antiplatelet therapy.

Note:

Antiplatelets Waiting period
Ticlopidine 14 days
Clopidogrel 7 days
Abciximab 48 hour
Eptifibatide 8 hour
 

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents (except SGLT-2 inhibitors)

Discontinue on the day of surgery

SGLT-2 inhibitors

Discontinue 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high risk surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior

questions.text: The following image depicts a biotechnology process. Choose the false statement regarding it.

choices.text: Hybrid cells lack the enzyme hypoxanthine phosphoribosyl transferase
Specific antibody-producing cells are integrated with myeloma cells
Hybrid cells are cultured in HAT medium

questions.solution:
The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology. Myeloma cells (not hybrid cells) are deficient in the enzyme HPRT (Hypoxanthine phosphoribosyl transferase).

Monoclonal antibodies refer to the antibodies produced by a group of lymphocytes that produce antibodies against a single antigen. These antibodies are produced by hybridoma technology. 

In this technology, the B-lymphocytes of mice spleen are immunized with an antigen to produce specific antibody. These specific antibody-producing B lymphocytes are then fused with myeloma cells that can multiply indefinitely.

The myeloma cells are deficient in the hypoxanthine-guanine-phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) gene and do not produce immunoglobulins. Therefore, the resulting hybrid cell is producing antibodies against a single antigen indefinitely. These hybrid cells are cultured in a HAT medium (containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine) and the monoclonal antibodies are obtained.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient was admitted to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, paradoxical respiration was seen. His chest X-ray is shown below. He was given analgesics and oxygen was administered via face mask but he developed respiratory failure. What is the best line of management of this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario alongwith the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side suggest Flail chest.

Flail chest is characterized by contiguous rib fractures and paradoxical respiration following blunt trauma to the chest wall. Mechanical ventilation (like Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is the management of flail chest with respiratory failure.

Flail Chest :

  • A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage.
  • This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures, i.e. 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places.
  • The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an underlying pulmonary contusion as well.

Clinical Features:

On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards and less air, therefore, moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards(paradoxical respiration).

Diagnosis - To confirm the diagnosis the chest wall can be observed for the paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment for several respiratory cycles and during coughing. Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement, and the associated lung contusion are all causes of hypoxia and respiratory failure.

The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

Treatment

  • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided
  • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia and physiotherapy.
  • IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for cases developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

Other options:

Option A: Chest tube drainage can be done in traumatic pulmonary contusion associated with pneumothorax or hemothorax

Option B: Intrapleural local analgesia can be given if the patient has a chest tube inserted. Since the chest tube drainage is only done after stabilising the patient, intrapleural analgesia is not the best line of treatment at this stage.

Option D: Surgical fixation of the fracture is done only in patients with severe chest injury and pulmonary contusion. Also, surgery should be proceeded only after the patient's condition is stabilised.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of weakness, weight loss, diarrhea, oily stools, and joint pain for about 6 months.  A diagnosis of malabsorption syndrome was suspected. A duodenal biopsy was done, and the findings are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea, weight loss, and chronic arthralgia and the given slide showing macrophages filled with PAS-positive inclusions points to a diagnosis of Whipple's disease.

Whipple's disease is a multi-system disease caused by infection with gram-positive bacillus Tropheryma whipplei. Clinical features include arthralgia and arthritis, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Arthralgias and arthritis are present for many years before the appearance of GI symptoms. CNS involvement is common and presents as psychiatric manifestations, memory problems, or ophthalmoplegia. Dementia may occur in later stages. Cardiac involvement may be in the form of endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis. Hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas may also be seen. Intermittent low-grade fever is present in most of the patients.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is primarily established by endoscopic biopsy and histological evaluation. Infiltration of lamina propria with PAS-positive macrophages containing the bacilli is diagnostic. The remainder of the cases are diagnosed by PCR, which can be done on duodenal biopsies or fluids (such as CSF and synovial fluid) or tissues.

The treatment regimen for Whipple's disease is ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks, followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months. Prolonged antibiotics are recommended, but there is still uncertainty prevailing regarding the optimal regimen.

Other options:

Option B: Celiac disease presents as a malabsorption syndrome due to the immune response to gluten in the diet. It is characterized by the presence of IgA antigliadin, anti-endomysial, and anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Histology will show a flat appearance of the intestine epithelium with crypt hyperplasia and villous atrophy. There is also an increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes and increased numbers of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the lamina propria. The image below shows the intestinal biopsy of a patient with celiac disease.

Option C: Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious etiology. It is predominantly seen in some tropical countries such as India. It is usually preceded by an episode of acute gastroenteritis. Small bowel biopsy resembles that of celiac disease. Treatment is with broad-spectrum antibiotics and folic acid.

Option D: Bacterial overgrowth causes deconjugation of bile acids and their deficiency in the lumen of the small intestine. This causes malabsorption, leading to diarrhea with steatorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following type of interactions is responsible for the stability of the following structure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a beta-sheet which is a secondary structure of proteins. They owe their stability to hydrogen bonds formed between two adjacent beta-sheets.

Proteins are arranged in the following four structures:

  • Primary
    • The sequence of amino acids in a protein is called a primary structure.
  • Secondary
    • The folding of short contiguous polypeptide sequences into geometrically ordered units.
    • Alpha helix and beta sheets are examples of secondary structure.
      • Alpha helix - It is the most common and stable secondary structure as a result of hydrogen bonds, supplemented by Van der Waal interactions.
      • Beta-sheets - They derive their stability from hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygens and amide hydrogens of peptide bonds between adjacent sheets.
    • Hydrogen bonds play an important role in the maintenance of the secondary structure.
    • Of this, beta sheets are represented as broad arrows, with the carboxy-terminal of the polypeptide chain at the tip of the arrow.
  •  Tertiary
    • This refers to the folding and final arrangement of domains in a polypeptide structure. In this, hydrophobic side chains are buried in the core whereas hydrophilic side chains are freely exposed.
    • An example of a tertiary structure is domain. These are the areas/structures of a protein that are capable of performing a particular chemical or physical task, for example, binding to a molecule, acting as a receptor, etc. 
    • Disulfide bonds, hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, and ionic interactions account for the stability of the structure.
  •  Quaternary
    • It is the arrangement of different polypeptide subunits in a protein

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient  presented with a painful and swollen right thumb following a fall on an outstretched hand with his thumb extended. The X-ray image of his right thumb is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows the avulsion fracture of the ulnar base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, known as Gamekeeper’s fracture.

A gamekeeper thumb, also known as skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx. Sometimes, a small fragment of the bone may be pulled off during the injury.

Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction.

Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint.

Diagnosis can be made on plain radiographs and/or anteroposterior stress radiographs.

Other options:

Option a: Bennet fracture: It is an intra-articular, two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone.

Option B: Rolando fracture is an intraarticular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, with a ‘T’ or ‘Y’ configuration.

Option D: Epibasal fracture of thumb, also known as pseudo bennett’s fracture is a two-part fracture of the proximal first metacarpal bone.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: The given image shows the various curves obtained for three different screening tests (A, B, C) employed on a population. Which of the following represents the correct match with respect to the Receiver-Operator-Curve (ROC) obtained in each of them?
questions.solution:
The correct match is A – 2, B – 1, C – 3.

The curves obtained mean the following:

  • A – There are some false negatives and some false positives as shown below. Therefore, the area under the curve is around 0.7 to 0.8. The ROC curve would thus be as shown in Image 2.
  • B – There are almost nil false positives or negatives. The test completely differentiates between healthy and diseased. Thus, the area under the ROC would be close to 0.9 to 1 as shown in Image 1.
  • C – The test does not differentiate between healthy and diseased people at all. The area under the curve for such tests would be 0.5 as represented by Image 3.

Note:

The ROC curve is a fundamental tool for diagnostic test evaluation. In a ROC curve the true positive rate (Sensitivity) is plotted in function of the false positive rate (100-Specificity) for different cut-off points of a parameter. Each point on the ROC curve represents a sensitivity/specificity pair corresponding to a particular decision threshold. The area under the ROC curve (AUC) is a measure of how well a parameter can distinguish between two diagnostic groups (diseased/normal).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with infertility, and a cervical mucus study was performed on the 24th day of her menstrual cycle (she has a regular 28 days cycle). Which of the following is not true regarding the interpretation of the findings shown in this test?

choices.text: This finding is due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus.
This phenomenon occurs under the influence of estrogen.
This test indicates that ovulation has occurred in this patient.
Corpus luteum is absent during this time of her cycle.

questions.solution:
The image shows a specimen of dried cervical mucus with ferning. It occurs under the influence of estrogen. The persistence of ferning beyond day 22 indicates anovulation. In this patient, ferning is present on the 24th day, which indicates that her cycles are anovulatory.

Fern test:

A drop of cervical mucus is spread and dried on a glass slide and observed under the low-power microscope. 

In the preovulatory (estrogenic) phase, a characteristic pattern of fern formation is observed due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus secreted under the estrogenic effect.

Following ovulation, ferning disappears due to progesterone activity. The disappearance of ferning is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity.

Insler devised a scoring system by just taking into account various properties of cervical mucus such as amount, ferning, and viscosity as an inexpensive test of ovulation.

questions.text: The image shows the inferior surface of the liver. Which lobe of the liver marked below forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen?
questions.solution:
The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen. The lobe marked as '3' in the above image represents the caudate lobe.

The caudate lobe is visible as a prominence on the inferior and posterior surfaces of the liver. It lies posterior to the porta hepatis and to its right is the groove for the inferior vena cava.

The caudate lobe of the liver has a portal blood supply and hepatic vein drainage independent of the remainder of the liver.

 Other markings:

1- Quadrate lobe

2- Left Lobe 

4- Right lobe 

Shown below are 2 views of the visceral surface of the liver -

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac):

  • It forms the communication between the lesser sac and the greater sac.
  • The roof is formed by the caudate process of the liver
  • The floor is formed by the superior part of the duodenum
  • The posterior wall is the peritoneum covering the subhepatic part of the inferior vena cava
  • The anterior wall is a free edge of lesser omentum containing a bile duct, portal vein, and hepatic artery.
  • It serves as a site for an internal hernia.

Related Pearl: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

Posterior
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

Superior
  • Caudate lobe of the liver

Inferior
  • 1st part of duodenum

 

Relations of lesser sac:

Anterior
  • Caudate lobe of liver
  • Lesser omentum

  • First 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

Structures forming the stomach bed:

  • Pancreas
  • Splenic artery
  • Left kidney and suprarenal gland

  • Left crus of the diaphragm

  • Transverse mesocolon

Inferior

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of diabetic retinopathy with proteinuria and the histopathological image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules with increased mesangial matrix is highly suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease is also known as nodular glomerulosclerosis or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis

Mesangial matrix appear as ovoid or spherical, acellular nodules in the periphery of the glomerulus. These nodules are PAS-positive. Capillary loops at the periphery are dilated. Accumulations of hyaline material occurs in the capillary loops (fibrin caps) and bowman capsules (capsular drops).

Other renal lesions that are seen in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, mainly hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Given below is another histopathology image of diffuse and nodular diabetic glomerulosclerosis (PAS stain). Diffuse increase in mesangial matrix and characteristic acellular PAS-positive nodules are seen.

Other options:

Option A: Diffuse lupus nephritis is the most common form of lupus nephritis (Class IV).

The lesions may be global or diffuse. It is characterized by the proliferation of endothelial, mesangial, and epithelial cells of the involved glomeruli. Subendothelial immune complex deposition forms a circumferential thickening of the capillary wall, resulting in wire-loop lesions.

The histopathology image given below shows a hypercellular glomerulus (endocapillary proliferation). Glomerular capillary loops appear circumferentially thickened, forming a "wire loop" lesion, which is classically seen in diffuse lupus nephritis.

Option B: Renal amyloidosis: The kidney is the most common organ involved in amyloidosis. Glomerular deposits appears as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid. Capillary lumens are obliterated.

Image below shows amyloidosis of the kidney. The glomerular architecture is almost totally obliterated by the massive accumulation of amyloid.

Option D: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with characteristic degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells as well as effacement of foot processes. Histology reveals focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall. Lipid droplets and foam cells are present in the sclerosed area.

Image below shows the histopathological image of FSGS.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with no significant past history comes to the emergency department with sudden onset of palpitations. On examination, her pulse is 140 bpm and her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Her ECG is given below. What will be the initial line of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as it shows narrow QRS complexes without visible p waves and pseudo R' waves in aVR lead. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, a carotid sinus massage will be provided as first-line therapy.

Vagal maneuvers like the carotid sinus massage and the Valsalva maneuver are techniques used to increase vagal parasympathetic tone.

Vagal maneuvers transiently increase the arterial pressure in the carotid sinuses and aortic arch. This triggers the baroreceptor reflex, which increases parasympathetic output to the heart via cranial nerve X. 

The right vagus nerve innervates the sinoatrial (SA) node and the left vagus nerve innervates the atrioventricular (AV) node. Stimulation of the right and left vagus nerve cause slowing of the electrical activity within the SA node and AV node.

Thus, vagal stimulation results in a decrease in the speed and frequency of electrical impulses in the heart, which could ultimately slow or terminate a tachydysrhythmia.

Treatment of PSVT:

In hemodynamically unstable patients, QRS-synchronous DC cardioversion should be done.

In hemodynamically stable patients,

  1. Vagal maneuvers such as carotid sinus massage are provided as first-line therapy only if there is a low risk of carotid vascular disease. It is contraindicated in patients with carotid bruit and prior history of stroke.
  2. If the vagal maneuvers fail or cannot be performed, intravenous adenosine can be used.
  3. If adenosine does not work, IV beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem) can be used
  4. Irregular, wide complex tachycardia can be treated with IV procainamide, ibutilide, or cardioversion. 

Care should be taken to perform continuous ECG monitoring with facilities for emergency cardioversion and defibrillation on standby.

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral nasal obstruction. On anterior rhinoscopy, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are found bilaterally suggestive of ethmoidal polyps. The surgeon plans functional endoscopic sinus surgery to remove them. Which of the following structures shown in the image given below is removed during infundibulotomy?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the ostiomeatal complex in the coronal plane. The structure marked as 1 is the uncinate process which is removed in infundibulotomy.

Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). FESS is the treatment of choice for ethmoidal polyps, which this patient has.

The structure marked as 2 is the ethmoidal bulla, and is removed in bullectomy.

The structure marked as 3 is the middle turbinate

The structure marked as 4 is the medial wall of the maxillary sinus.

Important steps in FESS:

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to casualty after falling from a balcony. Based on the CT scan finding provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above axial CT shows a hyperdense lentiform (biconvex) opacity, consistent with an epidural hematoma, which is a collection of blood between the inner surface of the skull and the outer periosteal layer of the dura mater, typically following a history of trauma. The characteristic biconvex shape arises due to the limited ability of blood to expand within the fixed attachment of periosteal dura to the cranial sutures. If bleeding is significant, it may lead to a mass effect with herniation. 

Additionally, a swirl sign may be present, representing acute blood extravasation into a hematoma (extradural/subdural), showing fresh, unclotted blood with lower attenuation than the clotted blood (which is of a higher attenuation), highlighting the need for surgical intervention.

The following CT image depicts a swirl sign:

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: You have been asked to present a case on homicide, with pictorial representations. You added the following image in your presentation. Which of the following is the mechanism of death in this form of homicide?
questions.solution:
The image shows smothering with a pillow, which involves the blockage of the external air passages. It can be performed by a hand as well. Death in smothering with a pillow is due to slow hypoxia.

Smothering is defined as a form of asphyxia that is caused by closing the external respiratory orifices either by the hand or by other means or blocking up the cavities of the nose and mouth by the introduction of a foreign substance. Smothering can be either accidental, suicidal, or homicidal.

Accidental smothering makes up most of the fatal smotherings. A person suffering from epilepsy or intoxicated by alcohol might accidentally lie in a position that restricts the airway which might consequently cause death. Falling into a large quantity of semisolid or fine material might also cause asphyxia by covering the openings of the airway. Children may be suffocated accidentally while playing with plastic bags and is seen often in people who are addicted to glue-sniffing.

Suicide by smothering is not possible using the hand. Psychiatric patients or prisoners might attempt suicide by burying their faces in a mattress or in their clothing. It can be attempted by tying a polythene bag over the head as well.

Homicidal smothering is a simple and convenient method of homicide because it is extremely difficult to prove as it may not leave any evidence. The mouth and nose are closed by a hand or cloth, or the face may be pressed into a pillow (gentle homicide).

Bruising of the inner surface of the lips may be seen if greater force is applied during smothering. At times, mucus and squamous respiratory epithelium from the victim may be found in the smothering material. In most cases, death is due to slow asphyxia where death occurs between three to five minutes. However, death in plastic bag suffocation is rapid due to reflex cardiac arrest, rather than a purely hypoxic process. (Option C)

Other options-

Option (A) and (D) both relate to causes of death which are observed in hanging.

Option (A): Cerebral anemia occurs when the noose of the rope is placed at the nape of the neck which causes compression of the large vessels (both arteries and veins). This causes death within 10 to 15 seconds due to cerebral anemia and consequent coma.

Option (D): Venous congestion is seen in cases where the knot is situated over the chin causing compression of the jugular veins. This in-turn stops cerebral circulation leading to a rise in the venous pressure in the head and subsequent loss of consciousness. A tension of 2kgs is required to occlude the jugular veins.

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the OPD with a sore throat and a rash, which appears as shown in the image, for the past 2 days. The rash started around the neck and then spread to the trunk and extremities. On examination, rash blanches on pressure. Tongue examination shows swollen papillae. Which of the following toxins is responsible for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scarlet fever, which is caused by a pyrogenic exotoxin produced by Group A streptococcus (GAS).

In scarlet fever, the rash appears within 24–48 hours of the onset of upper respiratory infections. It begins around the head and neck and spreads over the trunk and extremities. It usually spares palms, and soles. It is a diffuse, papular, and erythematous eruption, which blanches on pressure. The cheeks are erythematous, with pallor around the mouth. The tongue is usually coated, and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.

The image below shows a strawberry tongue.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum

questions.text: All of the following are the uses of enteric-coated drugs except:

choices.text: Protect the acid labile drug from gastric acidity
Protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects  of certain drugs
Prolongs the half life of the drug

questions.solution:
Enteric coating of the drug does not prolong the half-life of the drug.

The half-life of a drug depends on the volume of distribution and rate of clearance from the blood. It is given by t1/2 = 0.693x Volume of distribution / Clearance.

The enteric coating can be done for the following reasons:

  • Protection of active pharmaceutical ingredients, from the acidic environment of the stomach (e.g. enzymes and certain antibiotics).
  • To prevent gastric distress or nausea from a drug due to irritation (e.g. sodium salicylate).
  • For the delivery of drugs that are optimally absorbed in the small intestine to their primary absorption site in their most concentrated form.
  • To provide a delayed-release component for repeat action.
  • Required for minimizing the first-pass metabolism of the drug

questions.text: A newly married couple has come for counseling as the male partner has had difficulty maintaining an erection until the completion of sexual activity for the past 8 months. He does not have any known ailment. Which phase of the normal sexual cycle does this disorder belong to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of erectile dysfunction, which is a disorder of the arousal phase (excitement phase) of the normal sexual cycle.

Erectile dysfunction is marked by difficulty in achieving or maintaining an erection. A considerable decrease in penile rigidity during erection is also associated. All or one of these symptoms must be present during intercourse for at least six months for a diagnosis. It causes significant distress to the individual.

Patients who have had lifelong erectile disorder have never been able to obtain an erection sufficient for insertion. Acquired male erectile disorder is marked by successful penetration at some point in his sexual life but is now unable to do so. Erectile dysfunction experienced in particular circumstances is termed situational male erectile disorder.

Other options:

Option A: The desire phase consists of sexual fantasies and the desire to have sex. This phase is affected in people with frigidity(lack of sexual desire).

Option B: The orgasmic phase lasts for 3-15 seconds. It is marked by ejaculation. This phase is affected in people with premature ejaculation.

Option D: The resolution phase lasts for 10-15 minutes. If no orgasm is achieved, it can last for 1/2 -1 day. It is marked by full detumescence in 5-30 minutes. Detumescence is the release of vascular activity and muscle tone after orgasm.

Related Pearl: Sexual disorders

Address issues like guilt, anxiety, and fear

Relaxation techniques.

Female orgasmic disorder and delayed ejaculation: Recurrent or persistent inability to achieve orgasm either through masturbation or sexual intercourse

Genito-pelvic pain disorder: Pain associated with sexual intercourse in either male or female. Not diagnosed when the organic cause has been found or if due to vaginal lubrication.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following fundoscopic findings according to the respective grades in which they are seen, as per Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy, starting with grade 1.
  1. Macular star
  2. Optic Disc swelling
  3. Retinal arteriolar narrowing 
  4. Arteriovenous nipping
questions.solution:
The correct sequence according Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy is

3. Retinal arteriolar narrowing 

4. Arteriovenous nipping

1. Macular star

2. Optic Disc swelling

Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy:

Grade 1: Presence of mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing. 

Grade 2: Presence of focal arteriolar narrowing and arteriovenous nipping.

  • Copper wiring: Opacified appearance of arteriolar walls.
  • Salus’s sign: Deflection of retinal vein as it crosses the arteriole.
  • Gunn’s sign: Tapering of the retinal vein on either side of the AV crossing.
  • Bonnet’s sign: Banking of the retinal vein distal to the AV crossing.

Grade 3: Grade 2 plus retinal hemorrhages, exudates and macular star.

  • Retinal hemorrhages:
    • Dot-blot hemorrhages: Bleeding in the inner retinal layer
    • Flame shaped hemorrhage: Bleeding is in the superficial retinal layer
  • Retinal exudates:
    • Hard exudates: Lipid deposits in the retina
    • Soft exudates: These are also known as cotton wool spots which appear due to ischemia of the nerve fibers
  • Macular Changes
    • Macular star formation due to deposition of hard exudates around the macula.

Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling. This is a marker of malignant hypertension.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man, whose wife is a known case of leprosy, presents with the following skin lesions all over his body. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image with shiny papules and nodules on normal skin is suggestive of histoid leprosy. It is characterized by a very high bacillary load.

Histoid leprosy is a rare type of multibacillary leprosy where the bacilli are confined to the lesions and hence, globi are relatively few. The name arises from the microscopic finding of spindle-shaped histiocytes forming interlacing bands and whorls.

It was initially associated with dapsone monotherapy and irregular treatment, leading to the development of dapsone-resistant bacteria. It is now recognized to arise de novo also.

Lepra reactions are considered to be uncommon in histoid leprosy.
